page.title: 02Change in the Fens l900-85
page.content: Since drainage of the Fens in the 17th Century the district had been used as summer pasture land. It was not until the early years of the 20th century that its potential as rich agricultural land began to be realised. Today most of the block is intensively farmed by one large company, growing potatoes, sugar beet, cereals and carrots. Some grass is also grown for the company's dairy operations in the area to the North. The peat soil has wasted away to a great extent and now in some parts the clay soil beneath is exposed. At Shrub Hill there are some water filled pits which are all that remains of the brickworks on the site. This was served at one time by a rail link from the Ely-Norwich line, and in later years by part of the Wissington Light Railway, closed in 1957.
